subject: Gardening
title: Gravity Sensing in Roots
description: A short lesson to help you apply Gravity Sensing in Roots.

hook.text: Flip a seedling upside down and within hours, the root bends downward. Plants always know which way is down.

buildup.text: Root cap cells contain starch-filled granules called statoliths that settle to the lowest point of each cell.

discovery.text: When statoliths shift, they trigger hormone redistribution. Auxin concentrates on the lower side, bending growth.

twist.text: Astronauts tested this on the ISS. In microgravity, roots grow chaoticallyâ€”proving gravity is their primary compass.

climax.text: Plants carry their own internal plumb line. Every root tip has a gravity sensor as elegant as any engineered device.

punchline.text: Tiny starch grains are every plant's compass.

quiz.question: What are statoliths and what do they do in plant root cells?
options: Light-sensitive pigments that direct root growth toward water
Starch-filled granules that settle with gravity and trigger growth-directing hormones
Mineral crystals that store nutrients for root development
